newsitem.title: INDIA: India could take EC cotton duty issue to WTO.
newsitem.headline: India could take EC cotton duty issue to WTO.

text.p: India might appeal to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to intervene if the European Commission (EC) imposed an anti-dumping duty on grey cotton fabric imports, government officials said on Tuesday.
"We are thinking about it (taking the issue to the WTO)," a senior Indian Textiles Ministry official who asked not to be identified told Reuters.

The EC last week reopened inquiries over alleged dumping of grey cotton fabric by China, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Pakistan and Turkey after a complaint by Eurocoton, the Committee of the Cotton and allied Textile Industries of the European Union.
The issue was closed in May when a majority of EU trade ministers rejected the Commission's case for setting definitive dumping duties against the same six countries.
An Indian Commerce Ministry spokeswoman told Reuters that there were indications the duty on grey cotton fabric might be revived. "India's stance is that it is unfair," she said.
A senior official at the state-run Cotton Textiles Export Promotion Council told Reuters: "We are going to defend our case."
The official said that the EC, soon after dropping the move to impose anti-dumping duty on grey cotton fabric in May, imposed a duty ranging from 3.9 to 27.3 percent on bed linen imports from India.

Indian Commerce Minister B.B. Ramaiah told a meeting of parliamentary deputies on Monday that the move to impose the anti-dumping duty on grey cotton in addition to the duty on bed linen would adversely affect India's textile exports.
A senior Textiles Ministry official said that the country's exports would certainly be affected but the extent depended on the percentage of duty.
